questions.question: Which of the following is part of the Basis and Purpose of the Amateur Radio Service?

options.A: Providing personal radio communications for as many citizens as possible
options.B: Providing communications for international non-profit organizations
options.C: Advancing skills in the technical and communication phases of the radio art

questions.question: Which agency regulates and enforces the rules for the Amateur Radio Service in the United States?
What do the FCC rules state regarding the use of a phonetic alphabet for station identification in the Amateur Radio Service?

options.A: It is required when transmitting emergency messages
options.C: It is required when in contact with foreign stations

questions.question: How many operator/primary station license grants may be held by any one person?

options.C: One for each band on which the person plans to operate
options.D: One for each permanent station location from which the person plans to operate

questions.question: What proves that the FCC has issued an operator/primary license grant?

options.A: A printed copy of the certificate of successful completion of examination
options.B: An email notification from the NCVEC granting the license
options.C: The license appears in the FCC ULS database

questions.question: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a beacon?

options.A: A government transmitter marking the amateur radio band edges
options.B: A bulletin sent by the FCC to announce a national emergency
options.C: A continuous transmission of weather information authorized in the amateur bands by the National Weather Service
options.D: An amateur station transmitting communications for the purposes of observing propagation or related experimental activities

questions.question: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a space station?

options.C: An amateur station located more than 50 km above Earth's surface
options.D: An amateur station using amateur radio satellites for relay of signals

questions.question: Which of the following entities recommends transmit/receive channels and other parameters for auxiliary and repeater stations?

options.A: Frequency Spectrum Manager appointed by the FCC
options.B: Volunteer Frequency Coordinator recognized by local amateurs

questions.question: Who selects a Frequency Coordinator?

options.A: The FCC Office of Spectrum Management and Coordination Policy
options.B: The local chapter of the Office of National Council of Independent Frequency Coordinators
options.C: Amateur operators in a local or regional area whose stations are eligible to be repeater or auxiliary stations

questions.question: What is the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service (RACES)?

options.A: A radio service using amateur frequencies for emergency management or civil defense communications
options.B: A radio service using amateur stations for emergency management or civil defense communications
options.C: An emergency service using amateur operators certified by a civil defense organization as being enrolled in that organization

questions.question: Which of the following frequency ranges are available for phone operation by Technician licensees?
Which amateurs may contact the International Space Station (ISS) on VHF bands?

options.A: Any amateur holding a General class or higher license
options.B: Any amateur holding a Technician class or higher license
options.C: Any amateur holding a General class or higher license who has applied for and received approval from NASA
options.D: Any amateur holding a Technician class or higher license who has applied for and received approval from NASA

questions.question: Which frequency is in the 6 meter amateur band?
Which amateur band includes 146.52 MHz?
How may amateurs use the 219 to 220 MHz segment of 1.25 meter band?

options.D: Fixed digital message forwarding systems only

questions.question: On which HF bands does a Technician class operator have phone privileges?

options.C: 80 meter, 40 meter, 15 meter, and 10 meter bands

questions.question: Which of the following VHF/UHF band segments are limited to CW only?

options.A: 50.0 MHz to 50.1 MHz and 144.0 MHz to 144.1 MHz
options.B: 219 MHz to 220 MHz and 420.0 MHz to 420.1 MHz

questions.question: How are US amateurs restricted in segments of bands where the Amateur Radio Service is secondary?

options.A: U.S. amateurs may find non-amateur stations in those segments, and must avoid interfering with them
options.B: U.S. amateurs must give foreign amateur stations priority in those segments
options.C: International communications are not permitted in those segments
options.D: Digital transmissions are not permitted in those segments

questions.question: Why should you not set your transmit frequency to be exactly at the edge of an amateur band or sub-band?

options.A: To allow for calibration error in the transmitter frequency display
options.B: So that modulation sidebands do not extend beyond the band edge
options.C: To allow for transmitter frequency drift

questions.question: Where may SSB phone be used in amateur bands above 50 MHz?

options.A: Only in sub-bands allocated to General class or higher licensees
options.C: In at least some segment of all these bands
options.D: On any band if the power is limited to 25 watts

questions.question: What is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators in their HF band segments?
Except for some specific restrictions, what is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators using frequencies above 30 MHz?
For which license classes are new licenses currently available from the FCC?

options.B: Technician, Technician Plus, General, Amateur Extra

questions.question: Who may select a desired call sign under the vanity call sign rules?

options.A: Only a licensed amateur with a General or Amateur Extra Class license
options.B: Only a licensed amateur with an Amateur Extra Class license
options.C: Only a licensed amateur who has been licensed continuously for more than 10 years

questions.question: What types of international communications are an FCC-licensed amateur radio station permitted to make?

options.A: Communications incidental to the purposes of the Amateur Radio Service and remarks of a personal character
options.B: Communications incidental to conducting business or remarks of a personal nature
options.C: Only communications incidental to contest exchanges; all other communications are prohibited
options.D: Any communications that would be permitted by an international broadcast station

questions.question: What may happen if the FCC is unable to reach you by email?

options.A: Fine and suspension of operator license
options.B: Revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license
options.C: Revocation of access to the license record in the FCC system
options.D: Nothing; there is no such requirement

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid Technician class call sign format?
From which of the following locations may an FCC-licensed amateur station transmit?

options.A: From within any country that belongs to the International Telecommunication Union
options.B: From within any country that is a member of the United Nations
options.C: From anywhere within International Telecommunication Union (ITU) Regions 2 and 3
options.D: From any vessel or craft located in international waters and documented or registered in the United States

questions.question: Which of the following can result in revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license?

options.A: Failure to inform the FCC of any changes in the amateur station following performance of an RF safety environmental evaluation
options.B: Failure to provide and maintain a correct email address with the FCC
options.C: Failure to obtain FCC type acceptance prior to using a home-built transmitter
options.D: Failure to have a copy of your license available at your station

questions.question: What is the normal term for an FCC-issued amateur radio license?
What is the grace period for renewal if an amateur license expires?
How soon after passing the examination for your first amateur radio license may you transmit on the amateur radio bands?

options.A: Immediately on receiving your Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE)
options.B: As soon as your operator/station license grant appears on the ARRL website
options.C: As soon as your operator/station license grant appears in the FCC’s license database
options.D: As soon as you receive your license in the mail from the FCC

questions.question: If your license has expired and is still within the allowable grace period, may you continue to transmit on the amateur radio bands?

options.A: Yes, for up to two years
options.B: Yes, as soon as you apply for renewal
options.C: Yes, for up to one year
options.D: No, you must wait until the license has been renewed

questions.question: With which countries are FCC-licensed amateur radio stations prohibited from exchanging communications?

options.A: Any country whose administration has notified the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) that it objects to such communications
options.B: Any country whose administration has notified the American Radio Relay League (ARRL) that it objects to such communications
options.C: Any country banned from such communications by the International Amateur Radio Union (IARU)
options.D: Any country banned from making such communications by the American Radio Relay League (ARRL)

questions.question: Under which of the following circumstances are one-way transmissions by an amateur station prohibited?
When is it permissible to transmit messages encoded to obscure their meaning?

options.B: Only when transmitting certain approved digital codes
options.C: Only when transmitting control commands to space stations or radio control craft

questions.question: Under what conditions is an amateur station authorized to transmit music using a phone emission?

options.A: When incidental to an authorized retransmission of manned spacecraft communications
options.B: When the music produces no spurious emissions
options.C: When transmissions are limited to less than three minutes per hour
options.D: When the music is transmitted above 1280 MHz

questions.question: When may amateur radio operators use their stations to notify other amateurs of the availability of equipment for sale or trade?

options.B: When the equipment is not the personal property of either the station licensee, or the control operator, or their close relatives
options.C: When no profit is made on the sale
options.D: When selling amateur radio equipment and not on a regular basis

questions.question: What, if any, are the restrictions concerning transmission of language that may be considered indecent or obscene?

options.A: The FCC maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies
options.C: The ITU maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies

questions.question: What types of amateur stations can automatically retransmit the signals of other amateur stations?
In which of the following circumstances may the control operator of an amateur station receive compensation for operating that station?

options.A: When the communication is related to the sale of amateur equipment by the control operator's employer
options.B: When the communication is incidental to classroom instruction at an educational institution
options.C: When the communication is made to obtain emergency information for a local broadcast station

questions.question: When may amateur stations transmit information in support of broadcasting, program production, or news gathering, assuming no other means is available?

options.A: When such communications are directly related to the immediate safety of human life or protection of property
options.B: When broadcasting communications to or from the space shuttle
options.C: Where noncommercial programming is gathered and supplied exclusively to the National Public Radio network

questions.question: How does the FCC define broadcasting for the Amateur Radio Service?

options.B: Any transmission made by the licensed station
options.C: Transmission of messages directed only to amateur operators
options.D: Transmissions intended for reception by the general public

questions.question: When may an amateur station transmit without identifying on the air?

options.A: When the transmissions are of a brief nature to make station adjustments
options.C: When the transmitted power level is below 1 watt
options.D: When transmitting signals to control model craft

questions.question: When may an amateur station transmit without a control operator?

options.A: When using automatic control, such as in the case of a repeater
options.B: When the station licensee is away and another licensed amateur is using the station
options.C: When the transmitting station is an auxiliary station

questions.question: Who may be the control operator of a station communicating through an amateur satellite or space station?

options.A: Only an Amateur Extra Class operator
options.B: A General class or higher licensee with a satellite operator certification
options.C: Only an Amateur Extra Class operator who is also an AMSAT member
options.D: Any amateur allowed to transmit on the satellite uplink frequency

questions.question: Who must designate the station control operator?
What is an amateur station’s control point?

options.A: The location of the station’s transmitting antenna
options.B: The location of the station’s transmitting apparatus
options.C: The location at which the control operator function is performed
options.D: The mailing address of the station licensee

questions.question: When, under normal circumstances, may a Technician class licensee be the control operator of a station operating in an Amateur Extra Class band segment?

options.B: When designated as the control operator by an Amateur Extra Class licensee
options.C: As part of a multi-operator contest team
options.D: When using a club station whose trustee holds an Amateur Extra Class license

questions.question: When the control operator is not the station licensee, who is responsible for the proper operation of the station?

options.A: All licensed amateurs who are present at the operation
options.D: The control operator and the station licensee

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of automatic control?

options.B: Controlling a station over the internet
options.C: Using a computer or other device to send CW automatically
options.D: Using a computer or other device to identify automatically

questions.question: Which of the following are required for remote control operation?

options.A: The control operator must be at the control point
options.B: A control operator is required at all times
options.C: The control operator must indirectly manipulate the controls

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of remote control as defined in Part 97?

options.B: Operating the station over the internet
options.C: Controlling a model aircraft, boat, or car by amateur radio

questions.question: Who does the FCC presume to be the control operator of an amateur station, unless documentation to the contrary is in the station records?

options.C: The person operating the station equipment

questions.question: When must the station and its records be available for FCC inspection?

options.A: At any time ten days after notification by the FCC of such an inspection
options.B: At any time upon request by an FCC representative
options.C: At any time after written notification by the FCC of such inspection
options.D: Only when presented with a valid warrant by an FCC official or government agent

questions.question: How often must you identify with your FCC-assigned call sign when using tactical call signs such as “Race Headquarters”?

options.A: Never, the tactical call is sufficient
options.C: At the end of each communication and every ten minutes during a communication
options.D: At the end of every transmission

questions.question: When are you required to transmit your assigned call sign?

options.A: At the beginning of each contact, and every 10 minutes thereafter
options.B: At least once during each transmission
options.C: At least every 15 minutes during and at the end of a communication
options.D: At least every 10 minutes during and at the end of a communication

questions.question: What method of call sign identification is required for a station transmitting phone signals?

options.A: Send the call sign followed by the indicator RPT
options.B: Send the call sign using a CW or phone emission
options.C: Send the call sign followed by the indicator R
options.D: Send the call sign using only a phone emission

questions.question: Which of the following self-assigned indicators are acceptable when using a phone transmission?
Which of the following restrictions apply when a non-licensed person is allowed to speak to a foreign station using a station under the control of a licensed amateur operator?

options.A: The person must be a U.S. citizen
options.B: The foreign station must be in a country with which the U.S. has a third party agreement
options.C: The licensed control operator must do the station identification

questions.question: What is the definition of third party communications?

options.A: A message from a control operator to another amateur station control operator on behalf of another person
options.B: Amateur radio communications where three stations are in communications with one another
options.C: Operation when the transmitting equipment is licensed to a person other than the control operator
options.D: Temporary authorization for an unlicensed person to transmit on the amateur bands for technical experiments

questions.question: What type of amateur station simultaneously retransmits the signal of another amateur station on a different channel or channels?
Who is accountable if a repeater inadvertently retransmits communications that violate the FCC rules?

options.A: The control operator of the originating station
options.B: The control operator of the repeater
options.D: Both the originating station and the repeater owner

questions.question: Which of the following is a requirement for the issuance of a club station license grant?

options.A: The trustee must have an Amateur Extra Class operator license grant
options.B: The club must have at least four members
options.C: The club must be registered with the American Radio Relay League

questions.question: What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 2 meter band?
What is the national calling frequency for FM simplex operations in the 2 meter band?
What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 70 cm band?
How should you respond to a station calling CQ?

options.A: Transmit "CQ" followed by the other station’s call sign
options.B: Transmit your call sign followed by the other station’s call sign
options.C: Transmit the other station’s call sign followed by your call sign
options.D: Transmit a signal report followed by your call sign

questions.question: Which of the following is required when making on-the-air test transmissions?

options.B: Conduct tests only between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. local time
options.C: Notify the FCC of the transmissions

questions.question: What is meant by "repeater offset”?

options.A: The difference between a repeater’s transmit and receive frequencies
options.B: The repeater has a time delay to prevent interference
options.C: The repeater station identification is done on a separate frequency
options.D: The number of simultaneous transmit frequencies used by a repeater

questions.question: What is the meaning of the procedural signal “CQ”?

options.C: Only the called station should transmit

questions.question: Which of the following indicates that a station is listening on a repeater and looking for a contact?

options.A: “CQ CQ” followed by the repeater’s call sign
options.B: The station’s call sign followed by the word “monitoring”
options.C: The repeater call sign followed by the station’s call sign

questions.question: What term describes an amateur station that is transmitting and receiving on the same frequency?
What should you do before calling CQ?

options.A: Listen first to be sure that no one else is using the frequency
options.B: Ask if the frequency is in use
options.C: Make sure you are authorized to use that frequency

questions.question: How is a VHF/UHF transceiver’s “reverse” function used?

options.C: To listen on a repeater’s input frequency
options.D: To listen on a repeater’s output frequency

questions.question: What term describes the use of a sub-audible tone transmitted along with normal voice audio to open the squelch of a receiver?
Which of the following describes a linked repeater network?

options.A: A network of repeaters in which signals received by one repeater are transmitted by all the repeaters in the network
options.B: A single repeater with more than one receiver
options.C: Multiple repeaters with the same control operator
options.D: A system of repeaters linked by APRS

questions.question: Which of the following could be the reason you are unable to access a repeater whose output you can hear?

options.B: You are using the wrong CTCSS tone
options.C: You are using the wrong DCS code

questions.question: What would cause your FM transmission audio to be distorted on voice peaks?

options.D: Your transmit power is too high

questions.question: What type of signaling uses pairs of audio tones?
How can you join a digital repeater’s “talkgroup”?

options.A: Register your radio with the local FCC office
options.C: Program your radio with the group’s ID or code
options.D: Sign your call after the courtesy tone

questions.question: Which of the following applies when two stations transmitting on the same frequency interfere with each other?

options.A: The stations should negotiate continued use of the frequency
options.B: Both stations should choose another frequency to avoid conflict
options.C: Interference is inevitable, so no action is required
options.D: Use subaudible tones so both stations can share the frequency

questions.question: Why are simplex channels designated in the VHF/UHF band plans?

options.A: So stations within range of each other can communicate without tying up a repeater
options.D: So stations with simple transmitters can access the repeater without automated offset

questions.question: Which Q signal indicates that you are receiving interference from other stations?
Which Q signal indicates that you are changing frequency?
What is the purpose of the color code used on DMR repeater systems?

options.A: Must match the repeater color code for access
options.B: Defines the frequency pair to use
options.D: Defines the minimum signal level required for access

questions.question: What is the purpose of a squelch function?

options.A: Reduce a CW transmitter's key clicks
options.B: Mute the receiver audio when a signal is not present
options.C: Eliminate parasitic oscillations in an RF amplifier

questions.question: When do FCC rules NOT apply to the operation of an amateur station?

options.B: When operating under special FEMA rules
options.C: When operating under special ARES rules

questions.question: Which of the following are typical duties of a Net Control Station?

options.A: Choose the regular net meeting time and frequency
options.B: Ensure that all stations checking into the net are properly licensed for operation on the net frequency
options.C: Call the net to order and direct communications between stations checking in

questions.question: What technique is used to ensure that voice messages containing unusual words are received correctly?

options.A: Send the words by voice and Morse code
options.B: Speak very loudly into the microphone
options.C: Spell the words using a standard phonetic alphabet

questions.question: What is RACES?

options.A: An emergency organization combining amateur radio and citizens band operators and frequencies
options.C: A radio contest held in a short period, sometimes called a “sprint”
options.D: An FCC part 97 amateur radio service for civil defense communications during national emergencies

questions.question: What does the term “traffic” refer to in net operation?

options.B: The number of stations checking in and out of a net
options.C: Operation by mobile or portable stations
options.D: Requests to activate the net by a served agency

questions.question: What is the Amateur Radio Emergency Service (ARES)?

options.A: A group of licensed amateurs who have voluntarily registered their qualifications and equipment for communications duty in the public service
options.B: A group of licensed amateurs who are members of the military and who voluntarily agreed to provide message handling services in the case of an emergency
options.C: A training program that provides licensing courses for those interested in obtaining an amateur license to use during emergencies
options.D: A training program that certifies amateur operators for membership in the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service

questions.question: Which of the following is standard practice when you participate in a net?

options.A: When first responding to the net control station, transmit your call sign, name, and address as in the FCC database
options.B: Record the time of each of your transmissions
options.C: Unless you are reporting an emergency, transmit only when directed by the net control station

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of good traffic handling?

options.B: Making decisions as to whether messages are worthy of relay or delivery
options.C: Ensuring that any newsworthy messages are relayed to the news media

questions.question: Are amateur station control operators ever permitted to operate outside the frequency privileges of their license class?

options.B: Yes, but only when part of a FEMA emergency plan
options.C: Yes, but only when part of a RACES emergency plan
options.D: Yes, but only in situations involving the immediate safety of human life or protection of property

questions.question: What information is contained in the preamble of a formal traffic message?

options.A: The email address of the originating station
options.B: The address of the intended recipient
options.C: The telephone number of the addressee
options.D: Information needed to track the message

questions.question: What is meant by “check” in a radiogram header?

options.A: The number of words or word equivalents in the text portion of the message
options.B: The call sign of the originating station
options.C: A list of stations that have relayed the message
options.D: A box on the message form that indicates that the message was received and/or relayed

questions.question: Why do VHF signal strengths sometimes vary greatly when the antenna is moved only a few feet?

options.A: The signal path encounters different concentrations of water vapor
options.B: VHF ionospheric propagation is very sensitive to path length
options.C: Multipath propagation cancels or reinforces signals

questions.question: What is the effect of vegetation on UHF and microwave signals?
What antenna polarization is normally used for long-distance CW and SSB contacts on the VHF and UHF bands?
What happens when antennas at opposite ends of a VHF or UHF line of sight radio link are not using the same polarization?

options.A: The modulation sidebands might become inverted

questions.question: When using a directional antenna, how might your station be able to communicate with a distant repeater if buildings or obstructions are blocking the direct line of sight path?

options.A: Change from vertical to horizontal polarization
options.B: Try to find a path that reflects signals to the repeater

questions.question: What is the meaning of the term “picket fencing”?

options.A: Alternating transmissions during a net operation
options.B: Rapid flutter on mobile signals due to multipath propagation
options.C: A type of ground system used with vertical antennas

questions.question: What is a likely cause of irregular fading of signals propagated by the ionosphere?

options.A: Frequency shift due to Faraday rotation
options.D: Random combining of signals arriving via different paths

questions.question: Which of the following results from the fact that signals propagated by the ionosphere are elliptically polarized?

options.B: Either vertically or horizontally polarized antennas may be used for transmission or reception
options.D: Both the transmitting and receiving antennas must be of the same polarization

questions.question: What effect does multi-path propagation have on data transmissions?

options.A: Transmission rates must be increased by a factor equal to the number of separate paths observed
options.B: Transmission rates must be decreased by a factor equal to the number of separate paths observed
options.C: No significant changes will occur if the signals are transmitted using FM
options.D: Error rates are likely to increase

questions.question: Which region of the atmosphere can refract or bend HF and VHF radio waves?
What is the effect of fog and rain on signals in the 10 meter and 6 meter bands?
What is the relationship between the electric and magnetic fields of an electromagnetic wave?
What property of a radio wave defines its polarization?

options.A: The orientation of the electric field
options.B: The orientation of the magnetic field
options.C: The ratio of the energy in the magnetic field to the energy in the electric field
options.D: The ratio of the velocity to the wavelength

questions.question: What are the two components of a radio wave?
What is the velocity of a radio wave traveling through free space?

options.C: Speed inversely proportional to its wavelength
options.D: Speed that increases as the frequency increases

questions.question: What is the relationship between wavelength and frequency?

options.A: Wavelength gets longer as frequency increases
options.B: Wavelength gets shorter as frequency increases
options.D: Wavelength and frequency increase as path length increases

questions.question: What is the formula for converting frequency to approximate wavelength in meters?

options.A: Wavelength in meters equals frequency in hertz multiplied by 300
options.B: Wavelength in meters equals frequency in hertz divided by 300
options.C: Wavelength in meters equals frequency in megahertz divided by 300
options.D: Wavelength in meters equals 300 divided by frequency in megahertz

questions.question: In addition to frequency, which of the following is used to identify amateur radio bands?
What frequency range is referred to as VHF?
What frequency range is referred to as UHF?
What frequency range is referred to as HF?
What is the approximate velocity of a radio wave in free space?
What is a characteristic of HF communication compared with communications on VHF and higher frequencies?

options.C: Long-distance ionospheric propagation is far more common on HF
options.D: There is less atmospheric interference (static) on HF

questions.question: What is a characteristic of VHF signals received via auroral backscatter?

options.A: They are often received from 10,000 miles or more
options.B: They are distorted and signal strength varies considerably
options.C: They occur only during winter nighttime hours
options.D: They are generally strongest when your antenna is aimed west

questions.question: Which of the following types of propagation is most commonly associated with occasional strong signals on the 10, 6, and 2 meter bands from beyond the radio horizon?
Which of the following effects may allow radio signals to travel beyond obstructions between the transmitting and receiving stations?
What type of propagation is responsible for allowing over-the-horizon VHF and UHF communications to ranges of approximately 300 miles on a regular basis?
What band is best suited for communicating via meteor scatter?
What causes tropospheric ducting?

options.A: Discharges of lightning during electrical storms

questions.question: What is generally the best time for long-distance 10 meter band propagation via the F region?

options.A: From dawn to shortly after sunset during periods of high sunspot activity
options.B: From shortly after sunset to dawn during periods of high sunspot activity
options.C: From dawn to shortly after sunset during periods of low sunspot activity
options.D: From shortly after sunset to dawn during periods of low sunspot activity

questions.question: Which of the following bands may provide long-distance communications via the ionosphere’s F region during the peak of the sunspot cycle?
Why is the radio horizon for VHF and UHF signals more distant than the visual horizon?

options.A: Radio signals move somewhat faster than the speed of light
options.B: Radio waves are not blocked by dust particles
options.C: The atmosphere refracts radio waves slightly
options.D: Radio waves are blocked by dust particles

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate power supply rating for a typical 50 watt output mobile FM transceiver?
Which of the following should be considered when selecting an accessory SWR meter?

options.A: The frequency and power level at which the measurements will be made
options.B: The distance that the meter will be located from the antenna
options.C: The types of modulation being used at the station

questions.question: Why are short, heavy-gauge wires used for a transceiver’s DC power connection?

options.A: To minimize voltage drop when transmitting
options.B: To provide a good counterpoise for the antenna

questions.question: How are the transceiver audio input and output connected in a station configured to operate using FT8?

options.A: To a computer running a terminal program and connected to a terminal node controller unit
options.B: To the audio input and output of a computer running WSJT-X software
options.C: To an FT8 conversion unit, a keyboard, and a computer monitor
options.D: To a computer connected to the FT8converter.com website

questions.question: Where should an RF power meter be installed?

options.A: In the feed line, between the transmitter and antenna
options.C: In parallel with the push-to-talk line and the antenna
options.D: In the power supply cable, as close as possible to the radio

questions.question: What signals are used in a computer-radio interface for digital mode operation?

options.A: Receive and transmit mode, status, and location
options.C: Receive audio, transmit audio, and transmitter keying
options.D: NMEA GPS location and DC power

questions.question: Which of the following connections is made between a computer and a transceiver to use computer software when operating digital modes?

options.C: Computer “line in” to transceiver speaker connector
options.D: Computer “line out” to transceiver speaker connector

questions.question: Which of the following conductors is preferred for bonding at RF?

options.A: Copper braid removed from coaxial cable

questions.question: How can you determine the length of time that equipment can be powered from a battery?

options.A: Divide the watt-hour rating of the battery by the peak power consumption of the equipment
options.B: Divide the battery ampere-hour rating by the average current draw of the equipment
options.C: Multiply the watts per hour consumed by the equipment by the battery power rating
options.D: Multiply the square of the current rating of the battery by the input resistance of the equipment

questions.question: What function is performed with a transceiver and a digital mode hot spot?

options.A: Communication using digital voice or data systems via the internet
options.C: RTTY encoding and decoding without a computer
options.D: High-speed digital communications for meteor scatter

questions.question: Where should the negative power return of a mobile transceiver be connected in a vehicle?

options.A: At the 12 volt battery chassis ground
options.C: To any metal part of the vehicle

questions.question: What is an electronic keyer?

options.A: A device for switching antennas from transmit to receive
options.B: A device for voice activated switching from receive to transmit
options.C: A device that assists in manual sending of Morse code
options.D: An interlock to prevent unauthorized use of a radio

options.C: Change to a higher power level

options.B: Block the interfering signal with a filter on the amateur transmitter
options.C: Switch the transmitter from FM to SSB
options.D: Switch the transmitter to a narrow-band mode

questions.question: Which of the following actions should you take if a neighbor tells you that your station’s transmissions are interfering with their radio or TV reception?

options.B: Immediately turn off your transmitter and contact the nearest FCC office for assistance
options.C: Install a harmonic doubler on the output of your transmitter and tune it until the interference is eliminated

options.C: Installing bypass capacitors on the microphone cable

options.C: Make sure your station meets the standards of good amateur practice

questions.question: Which of the following precautions should be taken when measuring high voltages with a voltmeter?

options.A: Ensure that the voltmeter has very low impedance
options.B: Ensure that the voltmeter and leads are rated for use at the voltages to be measured
options.C: Ensure that the circuit is grounded through the voltmeter
options.D: Ensure that the voltmeter is set to the correct frequency

questions.question: What is required when climbing an antenna tower?

options.A: Have sufficient training on safe tower climbing techniques
options.B: Use appropriate tie-off to the tower at all times
options.C: Always wear an approved climbing harness

questions.question: Under what circumstances is it safe to climb a tower without a helper or observer?

options.A: When no electrical work is being performed
options.B: When no mechanical work is being performed
options.C: When the work being done is not more than 20 feet above the ground

questions.question: Which of the following is an important safety precaution to observe when putting up an antenna tower?

options.A: Wear a ground strap connected to your wrist at all times
options.B: Insulate the base of the tower to avoid lightning strikes
options.C: Look for and stay clear of any overhead electrical wires

questions.question: What is the purpose of a safety wire through a turnbuckle used to tension guy lines?

options.A: Secure the guy line if the turnbuckle breaks
options.B: Prevent loosening of the turnbuckle from vibration
options.C: Provide a ground path for lightning strikes
options.D: Provide an ability to measure for proper tensioning

questions.question: What is the minimum safe distance from a power line to allow when installing an antenna?

options.A: Add the height of the antenna to the height of the power line and multiply by a factor of 1.5
options.B: The height of the power line above ground
options.D: Enough so that if the antenna falls, no part of it can come closer than 10 feet to the power wires

questions.question: Which is a proper grounding method for a tower?

options.A: A single four-foot ground rod, driven into the ground no more than 12 inches from the base
options.B: A ferrite-core RF choke connected between the tower and ground
options.C: A connection between the tower base and a cold water pipe
options.D: Separate eight-foot ground rods for each tower leg, bonded to the tower and each other

questions.question: Why should you avoid attaching an antenna to a utility pole?

options.A: The antenna will not work properly because of induced voltages
options.B: The 60 Hz radiations from the feed line may increase the SWR
options.C: The antenna could contact high-voltage power lines

questions.question: Which of the following is true when installing grounding conductors used for lightning protection?

options.B: Wires must be carefully routed with precise right-angle bends

questions.question: Which of the following establishes grounding requirements for an amateur radio tower or antenna?
What type of radiation are radio signals?
At which of the following frequencies does maximum permissible exposure have the lowest value?
How does the allowable power density for RF safety change if duty cycle changes from 100 percent to 50 percent?

options.A: It increases by a factor of 3
options.C: It increases by a factor of 2
options.D: There is no adjustment allowed for lower duty cycle

questions.question: What factors affect the RF exposure of people near an amateur station antenna?

options.A: Frequency and power level of the RF field
options.B: Distance from the antenna to a person

questions.question: Why do exposure limits vary with frequency?

options.A: Lower frequency RF fields have more energy than higher frequency fields
options.B: Lower frequency RF fields do not penetrate the human body
options.C: Higher frequency RF fields are transient in nature
options.D: The human body absorbs more RF energy at some frequencies than at others

questions.question: Which of the following is an acceptable method to determine whether your station complies with FCC RF exposure regulations?

options.A: By calculation based on FCC OET Bulletin 65
options.B: By calculation based on computer modeling
options.C: By measurement of field strength using calibrated equipment

questions.question: Which of the following actions can reduce exposure to RF radiation?
How can you make sure your station stays in compliance with RF safety regulations?

options.A: By informing the FCC of any changes made in your station
options.B: By re-evaluating the station whenever an item in the transmitter or antenna system is changed
options.C: By making sure your antennas have low SWR

questions.question: Why is duty cycle one of the factors used to determine safe RF radiation exposure levels?

options.A: It affects the average exposure to radiation
options.B: It affects the peak exposure to radiation
options.C: It takes into account the antenna feed line loss
options.D: It takes into account the thermal effects of the final amplifier

questions.question: What is the definition of duty cycle during the averaging time for RF exposure?

options.A: The difference between the lowest power output and the highest power output of a transmitter
options.B: The difference between the PEP and average power output of a transmitter
options.C: The percentage of time that a transmitter is transmitting
options.D: The percentage of time that a transmitter is not transmitting

questions.question: How does RF radiation differ from ionizing radiation (radioactivity)?

options.A: RF radiation does not have sufficient energy to cause chemical changes in cells and damage DNA
options.B: RF radiation can only be detected with an RF dosimeter
options.C: RF radiation is limited in range to a few feet
